Fig. 1 Representative photo picture of the as-synthesized KAc/Cu-BTC#SiO2 hybrid gel synthesized with various KAc addition, where the denotation of n-K refers to the gram of KAc added. The synthesis mixture contained components with a molar ratio of Cu: BTC: TEOS: EtOH: H2O = 1:1.15:4.32: 166:537. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 (a) XRD patterns and (b) FTIR spectra of different as-synthesized KAc/Cu-BTC#SiO2 with various KAc addition. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 Schematic diagram for the KAc assisted in situ hybridization route to the KAc/Cu-BTC#SiO2 hybrid gel. Step description: i) hydrolysis and condensation of silicate to form silica gel, ii) coordination of BTC with Cu ions to form Cu-BTC, and iii) coordination of KAc with Cu ions to form Cu(CH3COO)2·nH2O. Fig. 3 Fig. 4 TG-DTA plots for the as-synthesized hybrid compound a) Cu-BTC#SiO2, b) 0.2 KAc/Cu-BTC#SiO2 and c) 0.5 KAc/Cu- BTC#SiO2. Fig. 4 Fig. 5 SEM images for the as-synthesized K-Cu#SiO2 catalysts with various KAc addition. Fig. 5 Fig. 6 (a) Nitrogen sorption plots and (b) pore size distribution derived from the BJH model for the Cu#SiO2 and K-Cu#SiO2. Fig. 6 Fig. 7 Wide-angle XRD patterns of various samples: a) Catalyst with different potassium content, the dotted gray frame (42–45° of 2 theta) was enlarged in b). Triangle refers to the metallic copper (JCPDS 04-0836) [28]. Fig. 7 Fig. 8 HRTEM images (a-f), particle size distribution (g-h), and HAADF image with element mapping (i) for the Cu#SiO2 and 0.5 K-Cu#SiO2. A regional area marked by yellow dotted frame in (e) is enlarged and shown in (f). Fig. 8 Fig. 9 XPS spectra of a) Cu 2p3/2 and b) K 2p for the Cu#SiO2 and K-Cu#SiO2. The reference sample K#SiO2 was synthesized using a similar procedure except for the addition of Cu(NO3)2. Fig. 9 Fig. 10 (a) Selective hydrogenation of furfural over copper catalysts with and various potassium content and b) Activity evolution of 0.5 K-Cu#SiO2 catalyst upon the calcination temperatures. The histogram and yellow circles stand for the FUR conversion and FOL selectivity, respectively. Reaction: 2 mmol furfural (FUR), 50 mg catalyst, 10 mL ethanol as solvent, reacted at 140 °C and p H2 of 2.0 MPa for 1 h. Fig. 10 Fig. 11 Structure characterization of various used copper catalysts: a) wide-angle XRD pattern with b) enlarged region (42–45° of 2 theta) from the dotted gray frame, c) Cu 2p3/2 XPS spectra and d) Cu LMM Auger spectra. Fig. 11 Fig. 12 a) Correlation between the molar ratio of copper species to silica (Cu+/Si and Cu0/Si) and FUR conversion, b) schematic diagram showing the role of Cu0 and Cu+ in the FUR hydrogenation. The molar ratio of Cu+/Si and Cu0/Si were calculated from XPS derived atomic ratio. Upgrading biomass platform molecules, e.g. furfural, to value-added fine chemicals has been intensively studied due to its promising potential to substitute the traditional petroleum route producing downstream chemicals. This study presents a high performance K-Cu#SiO2 catalyst derived from the hybrid of copper-based metal-organic-frameworks (Cu-BTC) and silica, for hydrogenation of furfural. The obtained K-Cu#SiO2 having uniformly dispersed copper nanoparticles (~5 nm), achieved a high furfuryl alcohol (FOL) yield (~33 molFOL/molCu h−1), as well as robust recycle utility (trace activity loss after 5 times recycle) at 140 °C and 2.0 MPa. The improved copper metal dispersion and abundant active sites dominating as Cu+/Cu0 species were responsible for the enhanced activity, both of which were closely associated with the functional role of potassium acetate (KAc) serving in the synthesized route. In one respect, the introduced KAc facilitated the Cu-BTC and silica to hybrid a uniform gel by balancing their hydrolysis or crystal growth rates, enabling strengthened copper-silica interactions to yield highly dispersed copper nanoparticles; furthermore, the KAc acted as an electronic regulator to tune the reducibility of copper species on K-Cu#SiO2 catalyst during subsequent N2-calcination. This work could shed a light on the synthesis of high-performance and robust silica-supported copper catalysts for biomass valorization. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords MOF Hybridization Potassium promotion Furfural hydrogenation Copper 1 Introduction In search of an alternative to the traditional petroleum resources, integrating bio-refinery with the renewable plant and crops to produce the downstream fine chemicals is a feasible route, which has caught much attention by numerous scientists [1]. By hydrolysis and fermentation, the cellulose and hemicellulose are extracted from the agricultural product and then transformed into platform molecules (e.g. furfural, 5-hydroxymethyl furfural, etc.) that be valorized into chemicals for various functions [2,3]. Recognizing that the furfural is highly oxidized organic molecules in comparison with most petrochemical products [4], the upgrading of furfural usually involves catalytic reduction, especially selective hydrogenation. Of these selected metal catalysts (Pt, Co, Ni, Ru, etc.) designed for hydrogenation [5–7], the copper-based catalysts find their diverse merits of preferential selectivity towards primary alcohol, acceptable cost and feasible applicability [8–18]. Yet two challenged hurdles have been impeding their usage for industrial practice [19]. One is the sluggish hydrogen adsorption on copper that requires high temperature or pressure to activate the reaction, the other is high vulnerability to metal sintering due to its low Tammann temperature. To address these shortcomings, many protocols including alloy second metals [20], confined space engineering [21], crystal plane control [16], acid-base sites alteration [22], and so on have been developed to improve the copper activity and sintering-resist properties. Several scientists have reported that the copper catalysts modified by the alkali metal, such as potassium and magnesium, exhibited intriguing promoted activity. For example, Stacchiola et al. disclosed that modified potassium can decrease the apparent activation energy for Cu2O reduction, and hinder the mass transfer of Cu atoms [23]. Palkovits et al. have announced that K-doping generated a higher number of O2-vacancies on CuCo x O y to enhance its oxidation activity [24]. Herskowitz’s group found that increased CO2 hydrogenation activity was associated with the reductive action of promoted potassium [25]. These research outcomes enlighten us that the copper modified by these alkali promoters would be beneficial to its FUR hydrogenation activity as a result of the redox properties alteration. To the best of our knowledge, research on the potassium promotional effect on the copper toward hydrogenation of furfural is limited [26]. Currently, usage of metal-organic framework (MOF) as both metal precursor and porosity template has been in the ascendant [27–35]. In this wave of catalysts engineering associated with MOF, the 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid copper salt, Cu3(BTC)2 (often abbreviated as Cu-BTC)—as known as the metal-organic framework HKUST-1 [33]—has undoubtedly been the one of the hottest MOF candidates to fabricate metal catalysts. The Cu-BTC was synthesized in advance and directly carbonized into a porous or graphical carbon-supported copper catalyst [8,27,30]. Unfortunately, this is very apt to cause severe metal sintering and uncontrollable copper particle size growth (20–100 nm); that’s because of the weak copper-carbon interaction and copper thermal properties mentioned above. Alternatively, other research groups have introduced inorganic support to compound with Cu-BTC. Thanks to the intensified copper-support interactions, the Cu/CeO2 [31], Cu/SiO2 [28], etc. catalysts with high copper dispersion were prepared. In our previous work [17], we have reported an efficient in situ hybridization strategy, in which the copper salts, BTC ligands, and silicate were simultaneously self-assembled into a uniform Cu-BTC#SiO2 hybrid gel by balancing the rates of silicate hydrolysis and Cu-BTC crystal growth. We found such homogeneous Cu-BTC#SiO2 hybrid gel enables close interaction between the silica and copper, which is the driving force underlying the modified copper dispersion and reducibility during the subsequent calcination. Albeit a comparable high FUR convert rate (9.2 molFURmolCu −1h−1) was recorded at that time for the optimized CuO#SiO2, we recognized that the real activity and metal utilization efficiency has unlikely been fully developed due to a considerable amount of copper existing as CuO species. There necessitates a further deliberate preparation technique or promoter design to get sufficient active sites available. Besides, realizing the synthesis of homogeneous hybrid gel under relatively mild reaction, e.g. lowered synthesis temperature or shortened procedure time, could be conducive to its coming practical application. In a continuing attempt to achieve a high-performance copper catalyst for FUR hydrogenation, herein we demonstrate a potassium acetate (KAc) assisted in situ hybridization strategy, in which the KAc serves as hybridization adjuster to promote the in situ hybridization process, as well as electronic promoter to yield active centers. The resulting K-Cu#SiO2 having highly metal dispersion (~5 nm) with an optimized proportion of reduced copper phase, showed significantly enhanced FUR hydrogenation performance. A series of detailed structure characterizations and control experiments were conducted to reveal the unique functional role of KAc in both hybridization and electronic synergy underlying this sound activity. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Catalyst preparation All chemicals were purchased commercially (Macklin, China) and used without further purification. In a typical synthetic process for the hybrid composite Cu-BTC#SiO2, firstly 0.25 g 1, 3, 5-benzenetricarboxylic acid (BTC) and 1 g tetraethyl orthosilicate (TEOS) were dissolved in 10 mL ethanol. Then, 0.25 g anhydrous cupric nitrate (Cu(NO3)2) was dissolved in 10 mL deionized water and added into the mixed solution. During stirring, 0.2–0.7 g anhydrous potassium acetate (KAc) was added into the final mixture, and the obtained components with a molar ratio of Cu: KAc: BTC: TEOS: EtOH: H2O = 1:2–7:1.15:4.32:166:537. The mixture was stirred for 30 min and transferred into a Teflon-lined autoclave for hydrothermal treatment at 120 °C for 6 h. The as-obtained hybridized gel was collected and dried at 60 °C overnight, denoted as KAc/Cu-BTC#SiO2. Finally, the as-prepared KAc/Cu-BTC#SiO2 sample was placed in a tubular furnace and calcinated at 400 °C for 4 h in the nitrogen atmosphere to obtain potassium promoted copper catalyst, denoted as K-Cu#SiO2. To investigate the effect of KAc content on the hybridization process, as well as on the physics-chemical properties of K-Cu#SiO2 catalysts, we prepared a series of n-K-Cu#SiO2 using a similar procedure except for the various addition of KAc, where the n stands for the mass of KAc addition. 2.2 Structure characterization Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) were carried out with a STA409PC thermogravimetric analyzer (Netzsch, German). The temperature range was 30–800 °C with a heating rate of 5 °C/min in a nitrogen atmosphere (25 mL/min). Fourier Transform Infrared Spectrometer (FTIR) was conducted on a Tensor 27 spectrometer (Bruker, USA) in the range of 400–4000 cm−1 with a resolution of 4 cm−1 to obtain IR spectra of the sample. X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were obtained with a D/Max-IIIA X-ray diffractometer (Rigaku, Japan) using Cu Kα radiation. Scanning electron microscope (SEM) was done using an S-4800 FESEM (Hitachi, Japan) to observe morphological and structural analysis. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) was carried out on a JEM-2010 microscope (JEOL, Japan) using an accelerating voltage of 200 kV. N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms were measured with a Tristar 3010 isothermal nitrogen sorption analyzer (Micromeritics, USA) using a continuous adsorption procedure. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was performed with an AXIS Ultra DLD (Kratos, Britain) to examine the electronic properties of catalysts. H2 temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) was performed on Auto Chem II 2920 instrument (Micromeritics, USA) equipped with a TCD. All the H2-TPR experiments were conducted with a 10 vol% H2/He mixture (50 cm3 min−1) (a heating rate of 5 °C min−1). Inductively coupled plasma-optical emission spectrometry (ICP-OES) was conducted on OPTIMA 8000DV (PerkinElmer, USA) to determine the copper content. 2.3 Catalyst evaluation Furfural hydrogenation was performed to evaluate the catalyst performance. In a typical experiment, 2 mmol furfural (FUR) and 50 mg catalyst were dispersed in 10 mL ethanol, then 2 mmol octane was then added as an internal standard substance. The mixture was transferred into a 25 mL autoclave (CF-0.05, HONGYI Instrument) equipped with a pressure gauge. The autoclave was sealed, purged with H2 four times, and then pressurized with H2 to the required pressure. The autoclave was heated to the required temperature and the reaction was left for the required time. The products after reaction were analyzed by GC (Shimadzu GC-2–14 C, FID) with a DM-WAX column (30 m × 0.32 mm × 0.25 µm) and GC-MS (Thermal Trace GC Ultra with a Polaris Q ion trap mass spectrometer equipped with a TR-5MS capillary column). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 In situ hybridization of Cu-BTC and silica assisted by KAc In our previous work [17], a homogeneous hybrid gel of Cu-BTC#SiO2 is synthesized under the hydrothermal treatment of 150 °C and 24 h. We have found that the key to synthesizing a homogeneous Cu-BTC#SiO2 hybrid is to control the rate of both Cu-BTC crystal growth and silicate hydrolysis, allowing the network of silica gel to disperse and stabilize the Cu-BTC particles. Thus the successful formation of homogeneous hybrid gel relies closely on sol-gel and coordinate kinetic. Considering energy and time-consuming in the previous protocol, herein we attempt to obtain the same uniform hybrid gel under relatively mild reaction (120 °C and 6 h) by controlling the self-assemble kinetic through KAc assistance. Fig. 1 witnesses the appearance evolution of the KAc/Cu-BTC#SiO2 hybrid along with the increasing KAc content. In the absence of KAc, the Cu-BTC#SiO2 shows clear phase segregation consisting of transparent silica light blue gel above and dark blue precipitation below. Increasing the KAc amount, the volume of precipitation expands gradually and forms a homogeneous blue hybrid gel finally as the KAc addition reaches 0.2 g. Such uniform hybrid gel can be retained as the KAc addition ranges in 0.2–0.5 g, yet some white discrete spots are seen on the surface of homogeneous gel for the sample with 0.5 g of KAc addition. This observation suggests that a proper addition of KAc can realize a uniform hybrid gel under lowered hydrothermal temperature (120 °C) and shortened time (6 h) relative to our previous method. To elucidate the assistant role of KAc in the hybridization, we performed the XRD and FTIR technique for the as-synthesized KAc/Cu-BTC#SiO2. Three diffraction peaks at 9.5, 11.7 and 13.5 ° of 2 theta ( Fig. 2a) indexed to a typical HKUST-1 like crystal phase (Cu3(BTC)2, indicated by gray circles [33]) are observed on the pristine Cu-BTC#SiO2, which diminishes gradually with the KAc addition; alternatively, several peaks associated with the copper acetate (Cu(CH3COO)2·nH2O, indicated by red diamonds [36]) emerges for the 0.2KAc/Cu-BTC#SiO2, and a sharp peak at ~ 10° of 2 theta ascribed to the lamellar basic copper acetate (Cu2(OH)3(CH3COO)·H2O, indicated by blue squares [37]) appears on the 0.5KAc/Cu-BTC#SiO2. This suggests that the Cu-BTC crystal is replaced by the copper acetate or basic copper acetate when raising the KAc content. As a consequence, we also see similar spectra change trend in the FTIR spectra (Fig. 2b). Several bands corresponding to the characteristic bands of the Cu-BTC compound [34,35] are found in these hybrid samples, in which the 1633 and 1554 cm−1 belong to the asymmetric stretching vibrations of carboxylate groups, 1446 and 1397 cm−1 correspond to the symmetric ones, and 1709 and 1237 cm−1 assigned to the CQO and C–OH combination bands of a carboxylic acid [38,39]. Increasing the KAc content, two adsorption region, 1709 and 1237 cm−1 representing to the C-O-Cu stretching of Cu-BTC, weaken gradually; while the FTIR band at 1554 and 1397 cm−1 associated with the absorbance of copper acetate (seeing Fig. S1 in ESI and Ref. [36]) become prominent. Therefore, based on the XRD and FTIR results, we speculate that the introduced KAc could compete with BTC for coordinating with copper ions, and affect the formation and growth rate of Cu-BTC. A possible in situ hybridization mechanism for the KAc assistance is proposed based on the above observations and characterizations, seeing Fig. 3. In the absence of KAc, the BTC coordinate with copper ions to yield Cu-BTC and its fast rate of crystal growth leads to the easy aggregation of large particles, making the silica gel network fail to uniformly disperse these Cu-BTC particles. Phase segregation with silica gel and Cu-BTC precipitation is finally obtained. As the KAc participates in the self-assembly process, thanks to the competitive coordination between the BTC and acetate with copper ions, the rate of Cu-BTC particle growth is controlled and minimized. A homogeneous Cu-BTC#SiO2 hybrid gel is achieved when the KAc addition is larger than 0.2. These results illustrate that a proper addition of KAc could realize a formation of homogeneous Cu-BTC#SiO2 hybrid under a relatively mild reaction (120 °C and 6 h). Fig. 4 shows the TG-DTA plots of different hybrid samples, preliminarily reflecting the change in pyrolysis kinetic of inorganic/organic molecules raised by the hybrid form. In general, the TG steps occur at low (<150 °C), medium (150–600 °C) and high-temperature ranges (>600 °C) represent the weight loss of physically adsorbed water and surface hydroxyl groups, pyrolysis of organic benzoic acid ligands [40], and dehydrogenation caused by the residual hydroxyl groups [17], respectively. Compared with the Cu-BTC#SiO2, the 0.2KAc/Cu-BTC#SiO2 has a few gentle TG steps ranging from 200 to 600 °C with multiple DTG peaks, indicating its complex and hard pyrolysis kinetics [18]. This agrees well with our previous finding that homogeneous hybridization enables a strengthened interaction between these precursors and silica. Such changed TG behavior become more prominent for the 0.5KAc/Cu-BTC#SiO2. Based on the enhanced interaction between the silica and ligands that contain node metals, we can predict a high copper metal dispersion could be obtained under the KAc assisted in situ hybridization protocol. 3.2 Alteration in morphology and structure properties raised by KAc addition Previously, the copper catalysts have limited reducibility when activated by air calcination [17]. Alternatively, herein we adopted thermal calcination under nitrogen instead of air atmosphere to activate these copper catalysts. The organic ligands pyrolysis and reduce the copper ions into metallic copper [8], and the KAc/Cu#SiO2 transforms into potassium promoted copper catalyst, denoted as K-Cu#SiO2. Besides affecting the hybrid gel formation, we found, the introduced KAc can serve as an electronic promoter and cause certain alterations in morphology and structure either. The SEM images ( Fig. 5) show the representative morphology evolution of as-prepared K-Cu#SiO2 with various KAc addition. Without the addition of KAc, the Cu#SiO2 shows an irregular and bulk aggregation; upon the addition of KAc, the 0.2 K-Cu#SiO2 presents numerous nano-rods with a length of 1 µm, and these nano-rods seem prolonged and aggregate as flower-like morphology on the 0.5 K-Cu#SiO2. The morphology evolution reflects the variance in hydrolysis kinetic and anisotropic particles growth during the hybrid synthesis. Using the nitrogen sorption technique, the porosity features of these calcinated samples are characterized ( Fig. 6a). The Cu#SiO2 displays a mixed adsorption model of type I and type IV: a steep rising adsorption at p/p 0 < 0.1 and a gradually increasing adsorption at p/p 0 between 0.2 and 0.8 suggest the presence of micropores and mesopores, respectively. Increasing the KAc content, the micropores volume decreases while the mesopores volume rises, especially for the inter-particle texture porosity. The corresponding pore size distribution plots (Fig. 6b) illustrate this trend more clearly, where the micropores volume diminishes along with mesopores size shifting from 3.3 nm to 15.6 nm (Table S1, ESI). Combined with the above XRD and SEM results, we assume, the micropores originate from the framework of residual carbonized Cu-BTC [31], which decreases when the formation and growth of Cu-BTC are limited by the KAc. The mesopores should mainly be sourced from the inter-texture of particles aggregation [41]. Fig. 7 shows the XRD patterns to provide information on the crystal state and metal dispersion of catalysts. As expected, all these calcinated samples have a metallic copper phase after nitrogen calcination at 400 °C, featured by three peaks located at 43.4, 50.4 and 74.1° of 2 theta (Fig. 7a)[28]. The (111) plane peak becomes broadened (Fig. 7b) along with the KAc addition, and a prominent shift (~0.12 ° of 2 theta) toward the low angle occurs on 0.5 K-Cu#SiO2. This suggests the alteration in both copper crystallite size and crystalline plane values caused by the potassium promoter, verifying the strong interaction between the potassium and copper during thermal activation [42]. The crystalize size of these copper catalysts were calculated by Scherrer equation, and the results are listed in Table S1 of ESI, showing the improved metal dispersion by the KAc addition. Furthermore, the 0.5 K-Cu#SiO2 catalyst calcinated by nitrogen at various temperatures, shows merely the metallic copper phase with enhanced peak intensity; no peak corresponding to the potassium oxide or other species related to the KAc experienced calcination (seeing Fig. S2a and b of ESI) is observed, even calcinated at 700 °C. It demonstrates the highly dispersed potassium species on the catalyst as a result of homogeneous hybridization. The improved metal dispersion of the calcinated K-Cu#SiO2 catalysts is further confirmed by the HRTEM images. The Cu#SiO2 shows a poly-dispersed copper nanoparticle ranging in 10–60 nm ( Fig. 8a-b and g), suggesting the easy-sintering properties of copper during reduction. For the 0.5 K-Cu#SiO2, spherical copper nanoparticles with a narrow size distribution (3–7 nm) peaking at 4.95 nm are evenly dispersed on the support (Fig. 8c-d and h). From the magnified region, the lattice value of 0.210 nm corresponds to the metallic copper (111) crystal plane (Fig. 8e-f) [8,27]. Moreover, the element mapping suggests the co-existence of Cu, Si, O and K, corresponding to the homogeneous hybrid characteristic. We can see that, the XRD derived particle sizes (d XRD ) are larger than the ones from TEM observation (d TEM ), especially for the K-Cu#SiO2 catalysts with smaller particles size (< 10 nm). Such variations between the values of d XRD and d TEM have been reported by other groups [8,43]. Probably these are due to the fact that X-ray gives crystallite size of a sample and TEM gives a size of individual particle in random, or while calculating particle size by integral width that whole of the peak broadening was due to crystallite size only [44]. To further characterize the electronic state of catalysts, XPS spectra were conducted. Considering the interference of residual carbon contained in the sample itself, we executed the calibration using the standard binding energy (BE) of Si 2p (103.0 eV). Asymmetrical peaks are observable in the Cu 2p3/2 spectra for the three samples ( Fig. 9a), which can be deconvoluted into two peaks at ~932.5 and ~934.0 eV, assigned to the reduced (Cu+/Cu0) and oxidized copper species (Cu2+), respectively [15,45]. The reduced phase dominates the total copper species, seen from the peak area, which also can be justified by the weak satellite peak at 946–942 eV that often accompany the peak of copper oxide [45]. Noticeably, ca. ~0.4 and 0.6 eV of low BE shift are seen for the 0.2 K-Cu#SiO2 and 0.5 K-Cu#SiO2, respectively, indicating the electronic state alteration occurred on the copper upon the K promotion. Two BEs located at 292.9 and 295.7 eV for the K-Cu#SiO2 (Fig. 9b) can be assigned to the K 2p3/2 and K 2p1/2 peaks, respectively, suggesting the existence of potassium oxides or cations [46]. Compared with the reference sample K#SiO2 that without the presence of copper, a high BE shift (~0.2 eV) of K 2p3/2 occurs upon the potassium promotion. Researchers have recognized early that either a change of particle sizes or electronic interactions can be responsible for such BE shifts [47]. In general, minimizing particle size cause high BE shift, as disclosed by Lercher [48] and Huang’s group [49], yet which seems to be paradoxical with our current case. Hence, considering the opposite BE shift of K 2p3/2, we intend to ascribe the low BE shift of copper to the electron transfer from the K to the Cu [26]. 3.3 Selective hydrogenation of furfural (FUR) to furfuryl alcohol (FOL) The selective hydrogenation of FUR was conducted in an autoclave reactor equipped with a pressure gauge and temperature controller. At the given reaction, the blank test without any catalyst shows slight FUR conversion (<1%), and the commercial copper (aver. Diameter 60–100 nm) shows a FUR conversion of 24% with a low reaction rate (<2 molFUR/molCu·h), seeing Entry 1–2, Table S2 in ESI. As shown in Fig. 10a, when using the newly synthesized Cu#SiO2 as the catalyst, the [50]catalyst performance. Initially increasing the KAc addition, the FUR conversion rises strikingly to 51% on 0.1 K-Cu#SiO2, then gradually elevates to the summit (94%) for the 0.5 K-Cu#SiO2 with a high reaction rate up to 33 molFUR/molCu·h. This is nearly 3.6 times higher than that our reported CuO#SiO2 previously did [17], also a comparable high reaction rate amongst these recent copper based catalysts developed by other groups [51–53]. Concerning the FOL selectivity, an excellent selectivity (>99%) is found over these K-promoted copper catalysts, suggesting that the potassium modification is favorable for the FOL yield. As discussed in our previous work [18], side reactions (esterification or aldol condensation) could be evoked by the acid sites on the catalyst, which seems to be depressed by the basic potassium modification. But excessive potassium loading can cause another by-product of 3-(2-furyl)acroein, seeing Fig. S3 of ESI. We guess, it could be associated with the in situ cross aldol condensation catalyzed by the excessive basic potassium [54]. The enhanced activity of K-Cu#SiO2 over the Cu#SiO2, we think, firstly should be benefit from their improved copper dispersion, as justified in the XRD pattern (Fig. 7) and HRTEM (Fig. 8). In addition, the contribution of altered electronic state raised by the potassium modification should be reckoned either, which will be discussed in the following correlation section. Then the effect of calcination temperature on the 0.5 K-Cu#SiO2 is studied, as shown in Fig. 10b. Similarly, the conversion rate accords with a volcanic trend, and the highest activity is found over the one calcinated at 400 °C. The rising activity upon the elevated temperature (<400 °C) should be ascribed to the improved reduction degree, leading to more reduced copper species; yet high temperature (>400 °C) is apt to cause metal sintering, as justified by the XRD patterns (Fig. S2a). Our results suggest the 400 °C is the optimized temperature that achieves a good balance between the reduction degree and metal sintering. Next, we conducted the reaction parameters screening for the 0.5 K-Cu#SiO2. As shown in Table S3 of ESI, trace reaction activity is recorded at 80 °C, this is because of the sluggish hydrogen adsorption on copper at low temperatures. Increasing the reaction temperature, the conversion remarkably enhances. While the FOL selectivity seems to be constant during the temperature given, suggesting the potassium promoting in the FOL selectivity. Similarly, with increasing hydrogen pressure, the reaction increases, but high pressure causes a little decline. Finally, the catalyst stability and regeneration was also tested. For the 0.5 K-Cu#SiO2, the used catalyst can recover almost 90% of its initial FUR conversion rate after facile regeneration of thermal treatment (Entry 9, Table S3). The stability may originate from the hybridization manner that realizes a close contact between the active components and support. We also performed a reference catalyst, 0.5 K-Cu#SiO2-IMP, in which the potassium was loaded on the Cu#SiO2 by impregnation and calcination. Underwent similar successive runs and regeneration, only 70% of its initial activity was recovered (Entry 10–11, Table S3). This demonstrates the robust stability of the K-Cu#SiO2 brought by the hybridization method. 3.4 Correlation between the hydrogenation activity and potassium promotion To observe the active copper state involved in the hydrogenation, we performed the XRD and XPS characterizations for the used catalysts. The spend catalysts seem to have a resemble XRD patterns as the fresh ones, presenting an exclusive metallic copper phase ( Fig. 11a). Yet viewed from the enlarged region of the XRD pattern (Fig. 11b), their peak intensity weakens to some extent, suggesting the change in the crystalline degree of copper. The corresponding XPS spectra (Fig. 11c) further confirm that the used catalysts have various copper composition. From the fitting peaks, the oxidized copper phase increase upon the potassium modification. To distinguish the reduced copper species separately, their Auger spectra (Fig. 11d) are fitted into two peaks indexed to the Cu+ and Cu0 [45,55], respectively. The potassium promoted catalysts have a high proposition of Cu+ than the Cu0. These results illustrate that the potassium promotion can regulate the copper reducibility, rendering the copper be easily oxidized into Cu+. Rout and co-authors have reported that the potassium synergy can retain the oxidized state of Cu+ by lowering Cu2+ reduction [56]. Similar research findings also have been reported on the potassium modified Fe-Cu/SiO2 and Co-Cu/TiO2 catalysts [57,58]. To verify this assumption, we have conducted the H2-TPR for these samples, in which the potassium-promoted copper catalysts have a high reduction temperature (Fig. S4 in ESI). Thus the modified catalysis properties of K-Cu#SiO2 can be seen as the surface alteration in composition and electronic state by the potassium synergy. Concerning the role of Cu0 and Cu+, both of them are identified as the active centers in the hydrogenation of molecules containing the carbonyl group, where the Cu0 and Cu+ are responsible for dissociating hydrogen and activating the carbonyl groups, respectively [8,59]. Considering that the XPS-derived atomic ratios could reflect the state and composition of the catalyst surface, where the reactant adsorption and hydrogenation occurs, herein we attempt to adopt the XPS-derived atomic ratios to correlate the activity with surface copper composition. Fig. 12a presents the correlation results of XPS-derived Cu+/Si and Cu0/Si with FUR conversion, respectively. The FUR conversion rises with the increasing of Cu+/Si ratio, which is negatively correlated with Cu0/Si ratio accordingly. This result points out that the surface Cu+, instead of Cu0 species, determine the final activity. Paradoxically, our previous results show that the metallic copper species dominate the overall hydrogenation activity [17,18]. In the research of hydrogenation of methyl acetate by Ma's group [60], they have once unraveled that, when the accessible metallic Cu surface area is below a certain value, the catalytic activity of hydrogenation linearly increases with increasing Cu0 surface area, whereas it is primarily affected by the Cu+ surface area. Thus our results can be reasonably explained as follow: in our previous work, both the CuO#TiO2 and CuO#SiO2 were activated by in situ reduction during hydrogenation, and had relatively low amount of metallic cooper species. The hydrogen dissociation on the Cu0 sites take charge of rate-determine step; turn to the current result, the K-Cu#SiO2 held high degree of reduction under nitrogen-calcination, where the hydrogen dissociation no longer limiting the overall activity, instead the activation of carbonyl group by Cu+ sites becomes the rate-determine step. A schematic diagram is shown in Fig. 12b to illustrate the respective role of Cu+ and Cu0 in the hydrogenation of furfural. 4 Conclusions To summarize, an efficient potassium acetate (KAc) assisted in situ hybridization route was developed to gain a high-performance potassium-promoted copper catalyst, K-Cu#SiO2, for furfural hydrogenation. By balancing the rate of silicate hydrolysis and Cu-BTC growth, the introduced KAc facilitates the Cu-BTC and silica to hybrid a uniform gel, which enables a strengthened copper-silica interaction to yield highly dispersed copper nanoparticles. Furthermore, the KAc serves as an electronic promoter to regulate the phys-chemical properties (porosity, reducibility, crystallite, etc) of copper species on K-Cu#SiO2 catalyst during subsequent N2-calcination. Applied for FUR hydrogenation, the K-Cu#SiO2 having uniformly dispersed copper nanoparticles (~5 nm), achieved a superior high furfuryl alcohol (FOL) yield (~33 molFOL/molCu·h−1) as well as robust recycle utility (small activity loss after 5 times recycle) at 140 °C and 2.0 MPa. coredata.dc:description: Upgrading biomass platform molecules, e.g. furfural, to value-added fine chemicals has been intensively studied due to its promising potential to substitute the traditional petroleum route producing downstream chemicals. This study presents a high performance K-Cu#SiO2 catalyst derived from the hybrid of copper-based metal-organic-frameworks (Cu-BTC) and silica, for hydrogenation of furfural. The obtained K-Cu#SiO2 having uniformly dispersed copper nanoparticles (~5 nm), achieved a high furfuryl alcohol (FOL) yield (~33 molFOL/molCu h−1), as well as robust recycle utility (trace activity loss after 5 times recycle) at 140 °C and 2.0 MPa. The improved copper metal dispersion and abundant active sites dominating as Cu+/Cu0 species were responsible for the enhanced activity, both of which were closely associated with the functional role of potassium acetate (KAc) serving in the synthesized route. In one respect, the introduced KAc facilitated the Cu-BTC and silica to hybrid a uniform gel by balancing their hydrolysis or crystal growth rates, enabling strengthened copper-silica interactions to yield highly dispersed copper nanoparticles; furthermore, the KAc acted as an electronic regulator to tune the reducibility of copper species on K-Cu#SiO2 catalyst during subsequent N2-calcination. This work could shed a light on the synthesis of high-performance and robust silica-supported copper catalysts for biomass valorization.
coredata.dc:title: MOF-silica hybrid derived high performance K-Cu#SiO2 catalyst for furfural valorization: The functional role of potassium acetate (KAc) in hybridization and copper electronic state
